review_blob:
Single bottle. Date seems to imply freshness past ~ late Feb.
Tulip Glass.
A:Peach colored haze with a finger of head. Good retention and lace but no bubbles visible though the haze.
S: Tart wheat, grain, maybe a bit of bubble gum.
T: Again, tart flavor with a wheaty note along with a slight vinous/apple finish. A bit of hop bitterness seems an afterthought. No booze detected. Cidery. 
M: Light, smooth body and average carbonation finishing clean and slightly fruity.
O: Not a style Im well versed in but not bad at all. Of course, Prairie pricing means itll be a long while before I have this again.

Bottle into a tulip. Bottled 7/10/15 so way past peak freshness but heavily discounted as such.
A: Medium orange color with a tight finger of beige foam. Good retention and sheets of lace.
S: Fragrant pithy scent with a little pine.
T: Bitter pine taste. A little citrus on the finish but thats all. Hardly any malt detected.
M: Medium heft with good crispness and carbonation. Slightly chewy finish.
O: Old bottle sure, but I dont find much to recommend above many other available pale ales. OK but I wouldnt seek it.

Undated 12 oz. can into a tulip.
A: Deep orange pour with a short, fading head of fine bubbles. Looks hazy and thick.
S: Mildly sweet pine/spruce scent with orange and honey notes.
T: Bitter orange and pine suggesting English ales. Malty and a bit roasty but not exactly sweet. Well balanced flavor. 
M: Medium heavy body with average level of carbonation fighting through.
O: Pretty good though a bit stronger than I prefer in a go-to pale. Worth having.
beer_name: Southern Star Pine Belt Pale Ale

review_blob:
Pint can dated 12/17/15. 
Into a tulip.
A: Gentle pour yields an inch of froth atop a pale yellow body with slow visible carbonation and fine suspended sediment . Good retention and patchy lace.
S: Faint tropical fruit scent. Pith buried deep. 
T: Dry pine flavor with lemony pith following on the finish. No malt and very little fruit. Bitter and simple.
M: Very light with a soft carbonation and clean bitter finish. High drinkability for sure.
O: Nice but didnt quite live up to hype. For the high ET price, you can do much better IMO.
beer_name: Evil Twin / 7venth Sun Citra Sunshine Slacker

review_blob:
Single bottle. Dated enjoy by Aug 2, 2016.
Tulip glass.
A: Pale yellow pour with tall frothy head that retains well. Little visible carbonation but clumps of lace .
S: Herbal hop scent with slight dry bready note.
T: Grassy hops half bitter half sour. Malt note also seems sour but not in a good way. 
M: Low-ish carbonation makes the light-medium body seem lifeless.
O: Cant believe I dont like this more. Maybe a bad bottle, but probably not a repeat purchase.

Can into a tulip.
Cant decipher the code on bottom of can but UPC is consistent with this years product. (sigh)
A: Mostly clear medium yellow with a fast-falling white head and little visible carbonation.
S: Bready pils-esque malt scent. Corn?
T: Fizzy and malty (?) A bit of a decent tart hop note. Not much happening really.
M: Light though full on the mouth with a clean tart finish.
O: Not a bad beer but wayyy overpriced for what you get. Oh well its a Wisconsin tick. You can do much better for much less.

Fucking 11 ounce bottle.
Bottled 3/17/16 so exactly 5 weeks old.
Rebranded Hoppy pale ale and kicked up to 5.2%abv.
A: Poured an inch of bubbles atop a a pale orange tinted gold in my tulip. Great retention with slow bubbles and patchy lace.
S: Sweet grapefruit and light pith with a hint of bread.
T: Dry pine upfront quickly followed by bitter grapefruit flesh then pith.
M: Thin body with a fairly strong bubble wash. Finishes clean and bone dry. Bracing and refreshing.
O: The beer itself is extremely good. Expensive of course but... Points taken though for the 11.2 oz. bottle. Easy recommendation.

Can dated best by 9/16/16 so 1 month old, into a tulip.
A: Pours mostly clear with a very fine haze topped off by a thick tight lasting head. Slow rising bubbles and blotchy lace.
S: Light scent of cracker malt with a hint of herbal hops.
T: Dry bitter hop note quickly followed by a small bloom of crackers or sourdough. Malty but not sweet. Hops fairly pronounced but do not overwhelm the great balance.
M: Light body with soft frothy carbonation. Very dry finish begs another sip.
O: My 1st Terrapin beer (!) is a very good warm weather sipper. Mild flavor and not too strong make this one I could drink all day. Highly recommended.
beer_name: Terrapin Georgia Theatre Session: Sound Czech

review_blob:
Bottle dated best by 06/19/16
Pilsner glass
A: Pours crystal clear medium gold with lots of large bubbles rising. Short bubbly head with patches of lace.
S: Pretty nondeScript smell of grass and sweet white bread.
T: A nice round biscuit/breadiness with just enough sweetness meets slight grassy hop bitterness. Good balance and refreshing taste. 
M: Medium body and clean drinking with slight resin in the finish. Average carbonation.
O: Nice pils although only slightly above average on most points. At least its not hopped all to hell for a change. Ultimately though, not worth $11/6.

12 ounce can into a tulip.
Canned 2/29/16.
A: Murky dark orange/gold with a tight eggshell colored head. Fair retention and impressive lace. Visible largeish bubbles and a little sediment.
S: Sweet spruce, orange and mango(?) scent. Very nice tart note too. Slightly peachy
T: Resinous tart pine with a fruity middle that is hard to specify. Maybe peach. Bitterness is there but fairly subtle. Oily finish. Very good balance.
M: Light and fairly thin as expected and frothy, finishing Pretty cleanly. Very crushable.
O: My first Bombshell beer is a pleasant surprise. Looks great. Smells great. Tastes great. A new addition to my list of favorite SIPAs.
UPDATED: MAR 29, 2016

12 oz. bottle stamped Enjoy by 5/23/2016 into a stange.
A: Pale yellow and pilsneresque. Little head and lace. A few bubble rising.
S: Surprising sweet lemon head candy smell. No malts readily evident. Reminds of Sixpoint Crisp.
T: Tart sharp piney dank bud flavor. Again looking for malt flavor but none stand out. Also thin for the ABV but tasty.
M: Thin in body and well carbonated. Finishes half bitter/half sour. Distinctive at least.
O: This took me quite by surprise in every aspect. Fairly unique and tasty brew though seems missing malt roundness at its strength. Nice overall though probably not a repeat purchase.

12 oz. bottle stamped Enjoy by 5/10/2016 into a stange.
A: 2 inch rolling head in my narrow kolsch glass. Mostly clear orange tinted gold pour with lively carbonation. Patchy lacing.
S: Caramel malts in the bottle, tart orange in the glass.
T: More pith and pine in flavor with grapefruit rather than orange the dominant fruit toward the finish. Bitter but with enough fruit to balance. A faint whiff of toast is all thats left of the malt flavor. 
M: Light bodied, crisp and clean finishing with a good carb scrub. Great drinkability.
O: Nice session ale. Aromatic, light, bracingly bitter, easy drinking and good if not terribly distinctive. Widely available and well priced = a repeat buy for me.
UPDATED: MAR 15, 2016

12 oz. can. Best by 4/8/2016
Standard pint
A: Dirty dark yellow color with a nice half inch of clingy foam. Busy carbonation seen.
S: A slight citrus edge on an otherwise malty aroma of sourdough.
T: Crisp and sour lemon flesh notes at front with pith following. A bit of grass and cracker noticed at the finish. 
M: Light but also slightly thick feel with a medium short finish and good carb tingle. 
O: Not sure if this strikes me more as a lager or an ale but pretty good tasting light fruity lager. Accessible and affordable so not a bad choice for knocking back a few.

12 oz can dated canned 111015.
Six pack actually named "Crazy Fresh Pils"
Into a pint glass
A: Hazy medium gold color with small tight head and large bubbles.
S: Crisp cracker malt scent with herbal/grassy hops blending in nicely.
T: Bitterness and bread hit the tongue at the same time with the biscuit fading and the resinous hop note lingering a bit longer. Pretty hoppy pils for sure. Hops just as pronounced though not as clean as in the nose. Not bad.
M: Feels a bit on the heavy side with hop resin on the medium length finish. This makes the beer not seem as refreshing and crisp as you may expect from a pilsner. 
O: Looks decent, smells really good and tastes pretty good too. Chewy finish was a bit unexpected but does not necessarily detract from the overall experience. This beer does exude quality ingredients and is not just another cookie-cutter pils. First time Ive seen this canned and it is worth trying at least if youre a NC pilsner fan.

12 oz. bottle into a pint glass.
Bottled 11/25/15
A: Washed out pale yellow with a slight haze. Little head, minimal retention and lacing.
S: Not sure I smell anything at all.
T: A little salty, a little tart, and a little like medicine that has been made to taste less like medicine.
M: Fizzy and light. A little watery.
O: This strikes me as a Michelob Ultra with an ounce of diluted lemon juice added.

12 oz. bottle date stamped 09/2016 into a shaker pint.
A: Pale yellow clear pour with a quickly falling bubbly head. Little lacing. Visible bubbles.
S: Light herbal hop scent and scant biscuit notes. Very European smell.
T: Bitter herbal/floral hop bite hits first. Doughy malts are then left in the bitter finish. Crisp, clean and refreshing. 
M: Crisp mouthfeel and average carbonation. Clean dry finish with a slight bitterness lingering at the end.
O: Just getting around to trying this champion pilsner. Quite good and drinkable but at $12/6 there are many better value options.

12 oz. bottle into a dirty shaker.
Bottled 8/28/2015.
A: Pours murky orange with a huge jagged white head that has dogged retention and thick lacing.
S: Cant smell much due to a headcold but I do get a sweet citrus tangerine scent. Will give an average rating to be fair.
T: Sweet caramel lasts but a fleeting second before a blast of bitter zest arrives and takes over. A tart fruity note joins in for the finish, providing good complexity. 
M: Medium heavy in body with a fine carbonation wash and a medium short finish. Surprisingly dry and clean with only a slight oiliness.
O: A bit unusual in my experience, this is pretty good though expensive at $12/6. I wont be buying this regularly (except maybe with TW coupons) but this is well worth a try if not an occasional purchase. Recommended.

12 oz. bottle dated 7/21/15 so out of freshness date by a few weeks.
Into a pilsner glass.
A: Poured hard as it was extremely cold. 1 finger of beige head that retains well to big bubbles after a couple minutes and never completely clears. Hazy dull orange and full of sediment..
S: Light sweet malt nose. and little hops noticed. Maybe a muted spicy hop note. Slight alcohol smell as it warmed.
T: Bitter orange taste overshadows the malty sweetness leaving a lightly resinous but clean taste at the finish. Earthy English hop taste with just a touch of orange.
M: Medium body with average level of carbonation. Medium length bitter but fairly clean finish. 
O: This beer gets raves but my bottle is out of date and honestly less than impressive in all areas. Some also may not like the level of shit floating around. I guess it deserves another chance...

16 0z. can poured into a pilsner.
Can stamped 215215270 whatever the fuck that means.
A: Cloudy dull orange pour with no huge head others have mentioned.
S: Muted scent of sweet caramel and orange marmalade.
T: Bitterness is fruity and tart. Sweetness in back as opposed to upfront in the nose. Not bad. 
M: Spritely carbonation and light medium body. 
O: Been wanting to try this for a long time. Tastes pretty good although I have no idea what a mango tastes like. At $11 for 4 pints though, probably not something I will buy regularly. Still I like that Its a "full blown" IPA at less than 6% ABV. Points taken for shitty job of date coding.

12 oz. bottle into a pilsner.
bottle dated best by 3/30/2016
A:Crystal clear pour of a pale washed out yellow with busy bubbles. Head left quickly to a bubbly ring.
S: Cracker malt smell typical of good German pils.Hops hidden but floral or herbal in aroma.
T: Bitter taste with crisp dry cracker malt and a slight pepperiness from the hops. Bone dry and refreshing with no sweetness to speak of. Great malt flavors. Not quite as hoppy as I expected based on the bottle deScription.
M: Very light bodied, gently carbonated, dry and crisp. Drinkability through the roof.
O: This beers simplicity is its best characteristic. Everything is what it should be with nothing special or superfluous. I think this is quite a good pilsner. Well worth buying if you are a pils fan as I am.

12 oz. bottle into a tulip
Bottle filled 12/30/15
A: Pours clear pale copper gold with an inch of pillowy foam. Average retention and lacing. Good amount of visible carbonation seen in bunches.
S: Sweet orange/tangerine on the nose along with a whiff of sweet bread dough or caramel. Light but nice
T: Bitter citrus flavors hit 1st followed by some citrus fruitiness. Not much pine. Dry toasted bread at the back. Pretty good.
M: Well carbonated but soft on the mouth. Not too heavy or boozy. Light body for the strength. Medium short finish is bitter but clean and fairly dry.
O: Impressive if unimposing in each aspect, this is now my 2nd favorite Highland beer to Gaelic Ale. A bit strong for my tastes but the price is nice too so I can see myself buying this again. A winner!

12 oz. bottle into a stange
DOB: 07/21/15 so quite old.
A: Pours a 2 finger tight head above swirling sediment in the dirty gold body. Great retention .
S: Light scent of herbs, earth and pine or spruce. No citrus. Sweetish smell.
T: A very light hint of citrus is quickly overtaken by pine bitterness. Not much to balance the taste. 
M: Pretty crisply carbonated and light bodied make this fairly quaffable and refreshing. 
O: Average SIPA at best. Drinkable although the taste is maybe not interesting enough to make me want to drink another. Of course this 6 pack is 6 months old so maybe a fresh sample is worth having.

12 oz. bottled 12/21/15 from a 12 pack poured into a tulip.
A: Pours a clear orange tinted pale gold With an inch of frothy head that after 2 minutes is down to a film over the top.
S: Citrus and warm spice on the nose. Low pine note. Very nice.
T: Earthy hop notes and light pine. Not nearly as much citrus as in the nose but its there. Slight malt sweetness provides good balance and is not the least bit cloying. Mild alcohol at the end. Good!
M: Fine beaded carbonation washes the tongue nicely. Light resin in the medium chewy finish.
O: Pleasantly surprised by this after being largely let down by the recent Cabin Pack. This is IMO worthy of its own 12 pack. Id buy again.

12 oz. bottled 12/13/15
Tulip glass
A: Clear pinkish gold pour with 1 finger of thick but diminishing head. Steady carbonation visible. Good looking thick lacing left.
S: Toasty bread maltiness. Slight caramel sweetness. NondeScript hops.
T: Earthy hop bite up first. Very English flavor. Toasted white or maybe sourdough bread later. Little sweetness.
M: Lively mouthfeel although doesnt look it. A little resin at the medium length finish.
O: Finally got around to reviewing this old friend. Nothing to complain about with this beer but I no longer find myself interested in it or the style. Still a good and worthwhile brew.

12 oz. bottle with no date info found even after being told by DB that this is on the bottleneck.
Tulip glass
A: Beautiful pour. Clear copper color with a short lasting head and patchy lacing. Few visible bubbles.
S: Malty with toffee and nut aromas. Moist brown bread.
T: Taste is also malty as expected with toasted nut and a bit of caramel sweetness. Also tastes watery. 
M: Light body and below average (flat) carbonation does not excite the tongue IMO. Slight lingering sweetness but it is not cloying.
O: Been intending to try this for a while. Now I know its just a mediocre amber lager. Watery malt taste and always expensive. OK but not impressed. Points off too for shitty (non-existent) date coding.

12 oz. bottle dated enjoy by 6/5/2016 into a tulip.
A: Liight pale gold with the slightest orange tint. 1 finger bubbly head above brilliantly clear body with a few bubbles visible. 
S: Sweet citrus, sweet evergreen smell. Not piney but more like spruce. Light scent overall. 
T: Bready at first which was unexpected. A toasty flavor along with citrus pith. Tart but not extremely bitter. A bit of alcohol in the end.
M: Average carbonation and light medium body. Short clean and wet finish with almost no resinous feel. Almost warming for 6% ABV.
O: Jumped at this as soon as it arrived at Total Wine. Im not a fan of adjuncts, but this is well done and good. Most IPAs are a bit too strong for my tastes but I can see drinking several sixpacks of this over the next few weeks. Citradelic indeed. Lets Take It To The Stage!

12 oz. bottle from Cabin Pack Box dated best by May 2016 
Bottle stamped 3435 so bottled 12/09/15
Chalice glass.
A: Almost no head from the pour, only a small collar of bubbles. Nice bright gold though, with tho occasional bubble wafting up. Expected darker color.
S: Biscuity malt scent is pilsner-like. Light herb or grass hop note. NondeScript but nice lager-like scent.
T: Hop bite right off the bat. Not much of the crisp biscuit from the nose. Dry/sour rye bread note that Im not sure I care for.
M: Light bodied as expected but also kind of coating and flat
O: Another forgettable beer from this damn cabin box. Not bad but no way Id buy this beer twice. SA should trim the fat. Save yourself the trouble.

12 oz. bottle from Cabin Pack
Box dated best by May 2016
Bottle stamped 3475 so bottled 12/13/15
Pilsner glass
A: Pours murky pale orange with a good inch of tight foam atop. Big bubbles seen rising. Good retention and lacing.
S: Sour bread and a little grass.
T: Wheaty roundness in taste. Brown bread crust. Slightly sour at the end.
M: Thin mouthfeel with lively carbonation. 
O: Im not a fan of wheat beers and nothing about this is changing my outlook. It looks better than it smells or tastes. Not bad but I cant imagine many people buying 12 packs of this. So far this is the only turd in the Cabin Pack. Average at best.

12 oz. bottle from Cabic Pack  
Box stamped Enjoy By May 2016
Actual bottle stamped 3455 so bottled on Dec. 11.
Poured into a Chalice.
A: Very cold pour left next to no head at all. Just a collar around the glass. Crystal clear jewel toned weak tea color. 2nd bottle poured a bit more of tan foam.
S: Lightly sweet malt and a little dark fruit/prune note on the nose. A little stout-like but very light. Again the beer is very cold. 
T: Roasty English hop bitterness with a hint of toffee sweetness at the back. Not getting peat nor smoke to speak of. Balanced and decent taste.
M: Slick and a bit oily. Medium bodied and almost flat. Shorter finish than I expected. Fairly clean and very softly carbonated.
O: I remember having this back in the 90s and finding it good but cloying after a short while but perhaps due to the cold temp Its fairly crisp and clean. Still pretty good although probably not something Id seek out unless perhaps I have a nice bottle of Scotch on hand.

Bottle from Cabin Pack mixed 12 pack
Box Stamped Enjoy by May, 2016 
Actual bottle stamped 3475 so bottled on 12/1315 
Into a Reisdorf stange.
A: Pours a turbulent finger high beige head. Slightly murky dark gold color with busy carbonation.
S: Dry scent of crisp white crackers and a touch of dry white wine grape.
T: Dry as expected with a starchy cracker bite. Grassy hop note is Echoes the white wine from the nose. Dry crisp, but strong tasting.
M: Light and very effervescent. Very easy-drinking. 
O: Overall pretty good example of a Kolsch if not exceptional. Two in a pack is OK but I would not be interested in purchasing six packs.

12 oz. can into a stange
Can is date coded but who can read this garbled shit
A: Hard pour yields 2" of tight fine foam. Light, mostly clear pale straw yellow.
Good head retention. Little visible carbonation.
S: Dry light smell of lemons and maybe a bit of wheat.
T: Yowsah, thats sour! That is all. 
M: Light, fizzy and dry. Good easy drinking beer.
O: Just not my thing evidently with the sour completely drowning out the salt. Theres no way I could drink two of these. Add to that expensive and rare in my area. They can keep this one. Of course points taken for shitty dating.

12 oz. can stamped best by 4/15/2016
Blvd tulip.
A:Can poured large head of frothy texture that held for several minutes atop a clear pinkish gold body with big bubbles visibly active. Thick lace.
S: Malty sweet/tart dark fruit smell. Not much in the way of hop zing. Smells sort of like an Amber Ale IMO.
T: Smoky roast bitterness greets the tongue, nicely balanced by a slightly sweet toffee malt note. Very English in flavor.
M: Medium heavy on the mouth with a bit of astringent resinous finish but otherwise quite clean. 
O: Pretty average English IPA I suppose. Body and flavor strike me as just about right for the ABV. Goes down pretty smoothly too. Nothing to really complain about but I guess I have become used to more American hop profiles now, as I would like another hop note to develop (not necessarily citrus) as this is a bit one-note. Overall I say "OK" but Im not impressed.
beer_name: Carolina Brewery Flagship India Pale Ale

review_blob:
12 oz. can into a stange
Can stamped best by 3/4/2016

A: A hard pour from the can yields 2 fingers of tight bubbly bone colored head. Good retention and nice lacing too. Clear medium gold body with a few lazy bubbles seen rising.

S: Dry white wine on the nose, slight grassy hop note. No malts detected. Light but fresh scent overall 

T: Tart hop pucker up front with dry white grape flavor on the finish. Not the least bit malty or sweet. Simple with little complexity, 

M: Very light soft texture with fine velvety foam giving a nice light dry and Champagne-like mouthfeel. Good but thin.

O: A respectable if not notable Kolsch but it really could benefit from a bit more malt heft and grain. Locally brewed, always available and well priced mean this is a nice anytime example of the style.
beer_name: Carolina Brewery Sky Blue Golden Ale

review_blob:
22 oz. bomber filled 12/16/2015 (!)
Pilsner glass
A: Deep cloudy orange brown with a thick, slowly diminishing head of beige. and thick lace.
S: Raisiny smell is an immediate turnoff for me. Not an IPA scent
T: Bitter sharp hop taste first off. Earthy or floral? Roasty malts provide a good foil. No dark fruit taste (yay).
M: Smooth and creamy texture with medium body. Finish is slick and bitter. 
O: Good looking and tasting ale though seems to be a niche product. Hate the RIS-like aroma but the taste is good and plenty bitter. Not bad but not a repeat purchase either.
UPDATED: JAN 8, 2016

12 oz. can into a stange.
Canned 09/03/15
A: Poured an entire glass full of head. Hand washed the glass so...unsure what happened here. Mostly clear brass colored body. Big rocky head looks like ice cream soda. Disappointed. OK fuck it, it looks like a beer.
S: Malty scent.
T: Roundly bitter hops flavor. Earthy and maybe a bit floral. Crisp malts noticed but definitely playing a supporting role. More APA taste than IPA.
M: Medium bodied with less carbonation than I expected considering the flood of head at the pour. 
O: The head overflow may have been my fault. However Average tasting beer + expensive as hell means I wont be buying this again.

11.2 oz. Euro bottle with no dating info found.
Standard pint glass
A: A hard pour yields very little head that dissipates after a minute or two. Clear pale yellow with lively carbonation visible. 
S: Very light scent of grape and green apple. Not much else.
T: Sharp and crisp tasting without much body to speak of. Fruity but not very tart or musty as some others of the style are. Very clean, obviously but lacking in depth.
M: Light bodied to the point of being watery. Average carbonation tingle does make it refreshing and slightly interesting. Could finish 6 of these without blinking.
O: Nice classic of the Kolsch style. Clean and drinkable with that characteristic fruity dry flavor. Champagne-esque is the highest compliment I can give. Overall no better than several American craft offerings of the same style, and not nearly as good as several others.
UPDATED: DEC 29, 2015

12 oz. bottle into a Tulip. 
Best by 2/24/2016
A: Pours an inch of head thanks to a furious swirl of carbonation. Settles quickly but not completely atop a clear brassy body. Patchy lace left.
S: Muted malt and some wood. little to no hop nose.
T: Hops are readily detected at first sip. A good dose of maltiness also there in balance. Trying to pick out woody notes but this is very discreet. Good tasting though somewhat reminiscent of a past-prime strong IPA. Tastes boozier than it is.
M: Light to medium body with soft carbonation providing a pretty nice mouthfeel.
O: Interesting and thankfully not overdone with the wood. Nice beer overall though not one I feel warrants seeking.

12 oz. can dated /01/2015
every can has the month unreadable.
Tulip glass
A: Brownish orange pour with a finger of thick foam that lasts a good few minutes. Good clarity with just a slight haze. Very little visible carbonation but pretty nice lacing left.
S: Very light scent of tangerine on the nose. Not much pine or malt detected. Extremely light nose overall.
T: Much more bitter on the tongue with pine coming in strongly. Much less citrus but some pith from mid to end sip.
M: Good stiffness on the otherwise light body. Good level of carbonation to clean up the finish which is well attenuated with next to no resin left on the mouth. 
O: Clean, crisp drinkable SIPA with a powerful if one dimensional hop flavor. This is not an exceptional beer but well worth a try if youre burned out on citrus hops. Mostly pine here though I prefer the juicy ones. Not bad at all.
Points taken for shitty job of date coding leaves an overall grade of just barely average.

12 oz. bottle dated:
BEST BY 05 APR 16
Pilsner glass
A: Clear light orange pours very little head but leaves good lacing.
S: Light crisp pine and dry citrus or bitter orange peel.
T: More zest than juice but very citrusy. Less piney. A bit of malt on the end. Pretty bitter and not very complex but quite good.
M: Very light and crisp body. Good carbonation, refreshing.
O: Another good bitter hop monster from GF. Im on board for an occasional purchase but not every week at $11/6.
beer_name: Green Flash Segal Ranch Session IPA

review_blob: UPDATED: DEC 26, 2015

12 oz.bottle with no date code found
Pilsner glass
A: Very nice looking bright crystal clear medium yellow with an inch of fluffy head atop and bubbles busily rising.
S: Malty, grainy smell without most of the skunk others have mentioned. Slight earthy hop note, so maybe thats it. Not much smell overall but nothing bad.
T: Crisp crackery malt taste with again a hit of earthiness. This actually is fairly reminiscent of a euro lager but not in a bad way. I do not taste corn. A little on the watery side but pretty good tasting.
M: Light bodied to the point of being a bit watery but nice bubble scrub makes it refreshing and easy drinking. Very clean finishing as expected.
O: This beer is overall pretty average but has good points. Nothing bad to report unless youre sensitive to earthy (skunky) hints. Not worth seeking but I bought this in a gas station and it was an outstanding choice considering the limited options. Points taken for lack of date coding leave my overall rating below average.

12 oz. bottle 
Dated 06/11/15 so near end of freshness range.
Pilsner glass
A;Poured a hazy dirty amber. Small head is gone quickly. Visible sediment seen in suspension. Not a really pretty beer to look at.
S: Sweet orange is dominant in the light scent.
T: Its citrusy but definitely not sweet. Bitter pith hoppiness is crisp and followed by a bit of cracker at the finish. Not complex but pretty good and bone dry. A slight fruity tartness at the very end of the sip is surprising and a nice bonus.
M: Medium light body with lively carbonation and clean dry finish makes this refreshing and drinkable. Not oily or particularly resinous. A brisk, stiff ale you can knock back all day.
O: This beer smells inviting, tastes refreshing and flavorful, and feels great going down. Just started to see Otter Creek products in my area so Im very pleased to recommend Over Easy to anyone looking for a new light ale. And this sixer is not even very fresh! Ill be buying a lot of this.

12 oz. bottle dated 9/21/2015 into a pilsner glass
A: A hard pour yields only 12" of beige foam that recedes rapidly to a collar and center bubbles. Clear ruby tea tinted brown color.
S: Some light roast and dark fruit on the nose.
T: Tart hops and roasty malt flavor. Neither cloyingly sweet nor burnt tasting.
Not very complex or heavy. 
M: Smooth and somewhat creamy mouthfeel with light to medium body. Wet and medium to long coating finish.
O: Tasty and drinkable, this is a very approachable dark lager. Always a bit expensive in my area though at 10.50/6. I like it and will continue to buy from time to time.

12 oz. bottle 
stamped Feb 2016
Chalice glass.
A: Crystal clear medium gold color with some a bubbles visible. Little head from the gentle pour but good sheets of lace.
S: Nice light grassy smell of hay and light toast.
T: Good balance of sharp sour bread balanced by mildly bitter herbal hop notes. Crisp and clean even if fairly nondeScript.
M: Light and crisp with a nice bite and a clean, dry bitter finish. Maybe a tad watery though.
O: Its no Noble Pils and not even a great replacement for it, but it is a serviceable pils, which will be widely available and competitively priced so sure, its worth an occasional purchase if you like the style.

12 oz. can into a pilsner glass
Can dated 09/09/15
A:Medium gold with a slight haze. Pours a finger high head of puffy cloud texture. Retains fairly well for a few minutes with good thick patches of lace. Small number of lazy bubbles seen.
S: Nice but light grassy, slightly lemony scent, Maybe a hint of alcohol as it warms but not grainy or malty to me.
T: Some booze detected early in the taste. Along with that lemony tartness from the nose. Malty as well for sure but I wouldnt call it sweet. Pretty well balanced and good. Tastes a bit stronger than it is. 
M: Medium to heavy feel for its strength with just enough tingle to keep it interesting. Clean though not exactly dry finish without much resin. Substantial beer.
O: Pretty good pils but more along the lines of a German IMO. Also, I dont necessarily find this a refreshing beer which is what I expect a pilsner to be since the smell is the only thing light about this. This will likely appeal greatly to those who like the taste of pilsners but want a bit stronger, heavier brew. Again, pretty good product overall and worth buying.
beer_name: Lost Rhino Rhino Chasers Pacific Pilsner

review_blob:
12 oz. can into a tulip.
Can dated 10/7/15, 3 weeks old
A: 1" tall coarse head lingers for several minutes atop a clear pale orange body. A little lacing in patches.
S: Sweet tangerine citrus greets the nose first from the can. A little spruce also. Not much maltiness.
T: Crisp sweetness from the malts combine with piney but round bitterness with citrus zest ending the finish.
M: Medium body with average carbonation level. Medium length finish is oily.
O: Nice complexity of flavors save this from mediocrity IMO. Among the freshest beers Ive had so this is as good as it gets evidently. Im not terribly impressed but not my favorite style.
beer_name: Cigar City Jai Alai India Pale Ale
